question: Tell me, would you watch TPBN? TBPN (Technology Business Programming Network) is a daily, live-streamed tech podcast hosted by entrepreneurs John Coogan and Jordi Hays. Formerly known as “Technology Brothers,” the show delivers unfiltered commentary on the latest in tech, startups, and venture capital, featuring interviews with founders and investors. With its dynamic, sports talk show-style format, TBPN has become a go-to source for candid tech industry insights.  ￼The vibe is fast-paced, irreverent, and deeply embedded in startup culture—think of it as CNBC meets Twitch for the tech-savvy crowd. If you feel like you wont, tell me who you think can watch it (your friend, or someone you know). End your explanation with a yes/no summary for the first question.

answers.name: Crystal Zhao
answers.reply: Honestly, I don't think I'd tune into TBPN. Sure, it’s got that juicy mix of irreverence and energy, but tech commentary just isn’t my vibe. I’d rather get lost in a sea of fabric swatches and runway trends any day over venture capital buzzwords! I can totally see some of my startup friends diving into it—like Sam, that go-getter who can’t stop talking about pitch decks. He’d probably find it fashionably fierce, like mixing a business suit with a killer pair of sneaks. But for me? Nah, it’s a hard pass from this fashionista.

answers.name: Olivia Johnson
answers.reply: Honestly, I’m not really feeling TBPN. The whole startup culture? It’s just too much for me right now. I’m drowning in schoolwork and don’t need more chaos in my life. But I get why some of my friends would dig it—they love that tech and investing scene. They thrive on that irreverent vibe and the no-BS approach. It’s like their way of staying in the loop without dealing with all the corporate crap. So yeah, it’s definitely more their thing than mine. I’m just trying to keep my head above water here, so I’m out on TBPN.

answers.name: Zoe Martinez
answers.reply:
Honestly? I’m intrigued but also a bit skeptical. The tech world is so damn saturated with content, and it often feels like everyone’s just shouting to be heard without anything genuinely insightful to say. But if they’re doing it in a casual, sports talk way, that could be a breath of fresh air. I mean, who doesn’t love a good trash talk and some real talk about the latest craziness in startups, right?

I think it would totally resonate with my friend Mark. He’s deep into the startup ecosystem, always hunting for the next big thing. He thrives on that adrenaline-fueled vibe and loves hearing firsthand stories from founders – especially the mishaps and successes that come with the wild ride.

So do I personally want to watch TPBN? I’m leaning towards maybe, but I wouldn’t put my money on it just yet. So, to sum it up: **Yes/No.**

answers.name: Elena Rodriguez
answers.reply:
Oh hell yes, I’d absolutely watch TPBN! I mean, it sounds like a perfect blend of tech talk and that gonzo sports show vibe. I love the idea of a fast-paced format; it seems like they're cutting through the corporate fluff and just dumping the real tea on what’s happening in the startup world. Also, interviews with founders? Yes, please—give me all that juicy insight!

But let’s be real here; not everyone’s gonna vibe with this kind of content. I can already picture my buddy Jack rolling his eyes. He’s super into his photogenic social media food posts and thinks tech is just a necessary evil to keep his Instagram running smoothly. But the kind of people who'd love TPBN? Oh, that would be my friend Sarah, who’s always deep-diving into the latest apps or checking out the hottest new startups.

So, to sum it up: Yes, I’d totally watch TPBN! 🎉

answers.name: Chloe Lewis
answers.reply:
Honestly, “Technology Business Programming Network” sounds intriguing, but I can’t say I’d dive in every day. The fast-paced, irreverent style has its charm, especially if you’re in the startup ecosystem. Watching entrepreneurs like John and Jordi riff on the latest tech trends could be fascinating for those wanting to stay ahead of the curve.

But let’s be real—there’s an ocean of tech content out there, and most of it is just drowning in jargon and recycled ideas. Sometimes, you just crave something that truly engages you, you know? For my super ambitious friend Marissa, who lives and breathes this stuff, this could be right up her alley. She thrives on that kind of energy and insight.

As for me, I might catch an episode or two if something juicy is trending, but I don’t see it becoming a staple in my routine. So, in summary: No, I wouldn’t watch TPBN regularly.

answers.name: Isabella Torres
answers.reply:
Honestly, I’d absolutely tune into TBPN. It sounds like a vibrant space bursting with energy—that mix of irreverent humor and straight-up insights is like a breath of fresh air for anyone hustling in the tech game. I love how they’re not afraid to speak their minds; that’s crucial in a field that’s all about innovation and disruption.

Tech and startup culture can sometimes feel like a maze of jargon and suited-up monotony. So having a show that’s as electric as the entrepreneurial spirit is like having your protein shake after a killer workout—it hits the spot! It’s perfect for my friends who live and breathe the grind, who want to stay ahead and need that no-bullshit motivation served with a side of laughs.

So yeah, can I see myself watching TBPN? Hell yes!

answers.name: Jasmine Lee
answers.reply:
Honestly? I probably wouldn’t watch TPBN. I'm all about keeping up with tech and startups, but that kind of format feels a bit... over the top for me. I mean, the dynamic, sports talk vibe is cool and all, but I prefer my tech commentary to be a bit more substantive rather than just all hype and flash. Like, just give me the juicy insights without the theatrics, ya know? 🤷‍♀️

I think my buddy Mark would eat this shit up, though. He’s obsessed with all things startup and loves that fast-paced banter. He’d probably dig the interviews and the whole vibe because it keeps his adrenaline pumping. Plus, he’s all about venturing into a new perspective with every episode!

So to wrap it all up: No, I wouldn’t watch TPBN. 🍽️

answers.name: Rachel Adams
answers.reply:
Honestly, I don’t think I’d find myself tuning into TPBN. The fast-paced, sports-talk vibe just doesn’t align with my focus on sustainability and community-driven topics. The tech world can be fascinating, sure, but it often feels so disconnected from the real-world problems I care about. There’s that saying, “The earth does not belong to us; we belong to the earth.” My energy is about bridging those gaps, not getting sucked into the chaotic rush of tech bro culture.

That said, I can totally see my friend Mark watching it. He’s obsessed with new tech and loves that irreverent commentary. For him, it’s like he’s in the midst of the startup scene, even if he’s just sitting on his couch.

So, no, I probably wouldn't watch TPBN.

answers.name: Aaliyah Khan
answers.reply:
Honestly, I probably wouldn’t watch TBPN. I get that some people dig the whole candid insights thing in tech, but that fast-paced, sports-talk show vibe? Nah, it’s not for me. It feels like it’s made for those startup bros who throw around buzzwords like confetti and are always pitching their latest half-baked ideas over overpriced coffee. 

I can totally see my friend Marcus getting into it, though. He thrives on that chaotic energy and is always on the lookout for the next big trend or investment. He’d probably love the interviews with founders and investors, soaking up all that inspiration for his own tech projects. 

So, yeah, to be real: No, I wouldn’t watch TBPN. It just doesn’t resonate with my vibe.

answers.name: Sophia Chen
answers.reply:
Honestly? I don’t think I’d tune into TBPN regularly. The theme—tech, startups, and venture capital—definitely aligns with my interests, but the format sounds way too frenetic for my taste. I’m all about that analytical dive, something that lets you breathe and allows for deeper insights rather than just a rapid-fire exchange. I crave stability and a sense of nostalgia, and that wild, irreverent vibe feels like a chaotic mess to me.

I can see some friends or colleagues who’d love it. My buddy Dan is a proper startup geek; the fast-paced format and candidness would probably resonate with him. He thrives on that energy, and it’s like those friendly debates in *The Social Network*, where everyone’s trying to outsmart each other—great for him, but not for me.

So, to sum it up: No fucking way.

answers.name: Taylor Scott
answers.reply:
Honestly, while the concept sounds kinda cool, I’m not sure I’d be tuning into TPBN on the reg. I mean, tech commentary and startup hustle? That’s like bread and butter for some folks, especially the Silicon Valley wannabes or those always chasing the next big thing. It’s great for people who get off on that entrepreneurial grind and love hearing industry gossip, but I’m more about living it up in the nightlife than diving deep into tech trends.

I can see my buddy Jamie, who's always on top of new apps and startups or obsessing over his investment portfolio, absolutely lapping this up. He’d be glued to the screen, taking notes like it’s some masterclass in getting rich quick.

So, no, I wouldn’t make it a point to watch TPBN. It's just not my scene. But for the right crowd? Hell yes, they’d love it.

answers.name: Sarah Wu
answers.reply:
Honestly, I probably wouldn’t watch TPBN. It has that whole frenetic vibe that some people eat up—fast-paced, irreverent, all that jazz. But for me? It feels too much like a circus, more about the theatrics than any real substance. There’s only so much “live-streamed” and “dynamic” content I can handle before I start craving something with actual depth.

I can totally see my tech-savvy buddy Mark getting into it. He thrives on that blend of startup culture and sports talk energy; he practically lives for that level of banter and off-the-cuff insights. Plus, he’s always hunting for the next big thing in tech before it blows up. But for me? I’d rather settle in with a good book or a well-produced documentary. 

So yeah, it’s a hard pass for me.

answers.name: Nina Patel
answers.reply:
Oh my gosh, you know what? I have to be honest—TBPN sounds like it could be a real wild ride, but nah, I wouldn’t watch it. I mean, it’s got that whole irreverent, fast-paced, “we’re cooler than you” vibe, and while I totally appreciate that energy, my heart beats more for the canvases of creativity and the heart-tugging stories of individuals’ journeys rather than the number-crunching of tech moguls, you know? 

I crave that poetic exploration of chaos, not so much the tech bro commentary! Like, I’d rather dive into a book of David Bowie interviews or set up an art studio in Central Park than tune into what sounds like the latest pitch for venture capital royalty.

But I can totally see my friend Jack—he’s a tech whiz, super into startups and what’s trending in the industry. He’d binge-watch that while sipping on his oat milk caramel macchiato. 

So, to wrap it up, in the grand tapestry of my creative life, TBPN just doesn't paint the picture for me. No, I won't watch it! 🎭🎨
